turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But don't you have to work?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: By a curious coincidence, it's my day off, too.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Bring me another, Ti-Joseph.  I have to keep the lady entertained.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: It must be hard work entertaining me if it requires six ounces of rum.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: What in the world are you talking about?  Six ounces -- ?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Higher mathematics.  Two ounces to a drink -- three drinks, six ounces.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: How do you know there's two ounces in a drink?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'm a nurse.  I always watch people when they pour something.  I watched Ti-Joseph and it was exactly two ounces.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Listen, did I tell you that story about the little mule at the plantation -- the little mule and Clement?  Let me tell you.  It's one of the funniest stories --

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Wait. I want to listen.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Don't let it bother you so, Wes.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Did you hear what he sang?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I wish I hadn't heard --

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Why?  Everybody else knows it. Paul saw to that.  Sometimes I think he planned the whole thing from the beginning -- just to watch me squirm.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That doesn't sound like him.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: That's right -- he's playing the noble husband for you, isn't he? That won't last long.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'd like to go now, Rand.  Would you mind taking me home?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: One of these days he'll start on you, the way he did on her.  "You think life's beautiful, don't you, Jessica?  You think you're beautiful, don't you, Jessica?"  What he could do to that word "beautiful." That's Paul's great weapon -- words.  He uses them the way other men use their fists.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Betsy, can I talk to you a minute?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Of course, Wes.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Does she suffer?  Does she know what she is?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I don't know.  I once asked Dr. Maxwell the same question.  He said he thought she was like a sleepwalker who would never waken.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: She hated sleep.  She used to say it was a thief -- stealing away her life, an hour at a time...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Not to a nurse.  Sleep is a cure.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: She's dead.  The dead ought to be buried.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But she's not dead, Wes.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: You know what she is!  That's death -- no mind, no senses -- no love, no hate, no feeling -- nothing!

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Please, Wes, do as I ask.  You must rest, you must sleep.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, Wes.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Jessica was never any good for Paul.  You will be, you are.  And Mother -- seeing Jessica day after day -- never able to escape, never able to forget.  Please, Betsy -- it's only merciful.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: It is not beautiful.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You read my thoughts, Mr. Holland.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: It's easy enough to read the thoughts of a newcomer. Everything seems beautiful because you don't understand.  Those flying fish -- they are not leaping for joy. They're jumping in terror.  Bigger fish want to eat them. That luminous water -- it takes its gleam from millions of tiny dead bodies. It's the glitter of putrescence.  There's no beauty here -- it's death and decay.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You can't really believe that.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Have the servants made you comfortable?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Yes, thank you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Can't I take it for you?

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: No, thank you.  Tomorrow's time enough for you to begin work.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I heard someone crying -- a woman --

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: A woman crying?  No one's been crying here.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Why was the maid crying?

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I'm not sure I can make you understand.  You know what this is?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: A figure of St. Sebastian.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Yes.  But it was once the figurehead of a slave ship.  That's where our people came from -- from the misery and pain of slavery. For generations they found life a burden. That's why they still weep when a child is born -- and make merry at a burial.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I made it clear in my letter to the company.  This is not a position for a frightened girl.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I am not a frightened girl.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: That's hard to believe, after what happened last night.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: If I were as timid as you seem to think, Mr. Holland, I wouldn't have gone into the tower in the first place.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: And what is so alarming about the tower, Miss Connell?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Nothing -- really.  But you must admit it's an eerie sort of place -- so dark --

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Surely nurses aren't afraid of the dark?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Of course not!

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: A mental case?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Why should you be?  My wife is a mental case.  Please keep that in mind, Miss Connell -- particularly when some of the foolish people of this island start talking to you about Zombies.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: You didn't find your patient so frightening in the daylight, did you?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Mrs. Holland must have been beautiful ---

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Many people thought her beautiful.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I suppose so.  Yes.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: And charming?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I've never given it much thought.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Don't.  It will save you a great deal of trouble and other people a great  unhappiness.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Good morning, Miss Connell.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I heard about your little misadventure yesterday, Miss Connell.  On your first "day off," too.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Well, I had a good time up to a point.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Wesley can be very entertaining.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Yes, he can.  But I've been wondering -- you know if you could leave the whisky decanter off the table --

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: It's always stood there, Miss Connell.  I can remember it in my grandfather's time and my father's. I'm afraid it will have to remain.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But for Wes -- it must be a temptation to him.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I've no sympathy with people who can't resist temptation.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Still, I feel you should remove the decanter.  Wes is not an alcoholic yet, Mr. Holland. But as a nurse I can tell you that it won't be long before he is.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I'm afraid the decanter will have to stay where it is.  I engaged you, Miss Connell, to take care of my wife, not my brother.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You don't seem very disturbed by it.  I've always thought Voodoo was something to be scared of: the drums sounded in the hills and everybody was frightened.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I'm afraid it's not very frightening.  They have their songs and dances and carry on and finally, as I understand it, one of the gods comes down and speaks through one of the people.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I heard you playing.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I often do.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I know what you went through tonight.  I kept thinking of what you said: that all good things died here, violently.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Why did you come in here?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I don't know.  I wanted to help you. And now that I'm here, I don't know how.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: You have helped me.  I want you to know I'm sorry I brought you here. When I thought of a nurse, I thought of someone hard and impersonal.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I love Fort Holland.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: What you saw tonight -- two brothers at each other's throat and a woman driven mad by her own husband?  Do you love that?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You didn't drive her mad.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Didn't I?  I don't know.  That's the simple truth of it.  I don't know.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: She is alive, Mr. Holland -- that's all.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Don't take it to heart, Betsy.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I imagined this so differently...

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I've been waiting here for hours, trying to imagine Jessica well again -- wondering what I'd feel. I could see Jessica as she used to be, I could hear her say in that sweet mocking voice, "Paul, darling..."  The whole thing beginning all over again...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: And instead,  I came -- bringing you nothing.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Instead -- you come, with sympathy, Betsy, and a generous heart. Don't forget that.  Don't call it nothing.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I wanted to help you.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Help me? How?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I took Mrs. Holland to the Houmfort.  I thought they might cure her.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: You have deliberately endangered Mrs. Holland's life.  There's no telling what you may have started with this insanity.  Why did you do it?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I told you.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Because you wanted to give my wife back to me?  Why should that mean anything to you?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You know why.  You saw it the other night at the piano.  You turned away from me.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: What I saw the other night, I didn't dare believe, Betsy --

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: You think I love Jessica and want her back. It is like you to think that -- clean, decent thinking.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: She was beautiful.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I hated her.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I still can't believe it Paul -- that you wouldn't say a word in your own defense.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I have no defense.  So far as I know -- it is true.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You can't believe that.  You don't know what viciousness it would take to drive a person mad.  You're not vicious or cruel, Paul.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: How do you know I'm not?  I was cruel to Jessica.  When I got to know her -- when I found out how empty and ungenerous she was, there was something about her -- something smooth and false -- that made we want to hurt her.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I can understand that.  Everyone feels that way about someone.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: No.  It's not just how I felt toward Jessica.  I've been cruel to even you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You wanted to warn me...

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: The night you came to me in this room -- to comfort me, to help me -- I turned you away.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Don't, Paul -- don't doubt yourself -- don't make me doubt you.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I remember words I said to Jessica - words mixed like to poison -- to hurt her, to madden her.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That's past -- that's over and done with...

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I want you to be safe, Betsy.  I want to know you're away from this place -- home again, where nothing can harm you -- nothing and no one.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You want that?

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Considering that the paper is three months old and this isn't Sunday -- no thank you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I guess I'll wait until I'm home, Mrs. Rand.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I wouldn't worry too much, Commissioner.  It'll pass.  We've had this sort of thing before.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: This is something else.  They're curious.  Curiosity and religious fervor make a strange and explosive mixture.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I'm quite sure nothing will happen, Doctor.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Wesley!

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: I am afraid, Wesley, he has that right.  And I will have to urge him to use it.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: I think I do.  I've often talked a little voodoo to get medicine down a patient's throat.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: It's more than that, Doctor.  I've entered into their ceremonies - pretended to be possessed by their gods...

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: And what happened then, Mrs. Rand?

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I hated myself.  I kept saying to myself over and over again that these people had no power; they had no strange drugs; that there is no such thing as a Zombie.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Ah -- that's where reason took hold.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Yes, I said it, and I made myself believe it. But when I got here, Jessica was already raging with fever.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Two things had happened, Mrs. Rand. One was that your daughter-in-law had been taken ill with a fever. The other thing -- completely disconnected -- was that you had wished her ill, because she had hurt your sons.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: But I had no thought of harming her.  It wasn't I...

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: You were possessed.  That is true -- possessed by your subconscious mind.  You were in the Houmfort, surrounded by their symbols.  To them, nothing worse can happen to a person than to be made into a Zombie.  Your subconscious mind used their own words for evil.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: All that you say comes down to the same thing.  You are asking me to pass a sentence of life or death on my own wife.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Insulin shock treatment is an extreme measure, Mr. Holland. But -- as Miss Connell pointed out when she suggested it -- this is an extreme case.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: You admit that it is terribly dangerous. Why do you advise it?

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: I don't know -- I don't know--

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: It is a hard decision to make -- but yours is only a technical responsibility...

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Technical responsibility, real responsibility -- what difference does it make?  Jessica lives -- or she dies. That's what we're talking about!

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: But I assure you, Father Walters, Miss Connell had no idea of the consequences when she went there.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Paul, we're not trying to blame Miss Connell.  It isn't a question of blame.  It's a question of what we are to do with Jessica.  The commissioner is very concerned.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: An accident at the mill?

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: No -- it's about Mrs. Holland.  A result of our discussion the other day, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: What about her?

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: In view of all the circumstances, the commissioner has decided on a legal investigation.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Investigation of what?

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Of the nature of Mrs. Holland's illness.  And, of course, the events which led up to it.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: In other words, I'm on trial.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: I did everything I could to forestall this, Paul.  I don't think there's any question of your innocence in the matter.  But there's been too much talk.  The thing's out of hand.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Maybe it's better this way, Mother. I'm glad you're going home, Betsy -- you'll be out of the mess.

turns.speaker: HOLLAND
turns.text: Dr. Maxwell is right, Mother.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Emotion tricks all of us, Mrs. Rand.  And you are a woman with a very strong conscience.  That conscience has been tormenting you. The rest is coincidence.  There is no such thing as a Zombie.  The dead do not come back to life. Death is final.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Well, Jeffries, why come to us about it?  Why don't you go up to the Houmfort and put a stop to the drumming and dancing -- that's what causes all the trouble.

turns.speaker: JEFFRIES
turns.text: No.  You're quite wrong.  Right here's the seat of the trouble. Mrs. Holland has become an object of speculation and religious interest to these people.  It's revived all their old superstitions -- Zombies -- and that sort of nonsense.

turns.speaker: JEFFRIES
turns.text: If I were as sure as you, Mrs. Rand, we wouldn't be here.  I'll tell you quite bluntly: for the peace of the island and possibly for her own safety, we've come to ask you to send Mrs. Holland away to St. Thomas.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: To the asylum?

turns.speaker: JEFFRIES
turns.text: I believe there's a kinder name for it, Wesley. At St. Thomas, it's called the Institute for Mental Therapy.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: It doesn't matter what you call it. I can tell you right now Jessica isn't going!

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I tell you he hasn't and he wouldn't dare use it if he had.

turns.speaker: JEFFRIES
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Because he drove Jessica insane -- deliberately -- coldly!

turns.speaker: JEFFRIES
turns.text: That could be a serious accusation, Rand, if it weren't a foolish one.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Foolish?  Tell them how foolish it is, Paul -- tell them!

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Dr. Maxwell -- it's nice to see you.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Dr. Maxwell has very unpleasant news for us.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: We're all in it.  There won't be a shred of pride or decency left for any of use.  Say something, Paul!  You've always been good with words.  Put some together, now, and tell us that you're not responsible -- that every damnable bit of it doesn't rest squarely on your shoulders!

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: You're wrong, Wesley.  The guilt is mine -- all of it.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Are you going to lie for him, Mother?

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Betsy, tell them about the Houmfort.  Tell them what you saw there.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: That isn't true.  You never understood her.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: That night, I went to the Houmfort. I kept seeing Jessica's face -- smiling -- smiling because two men hated each other -- because she was beautiful enough to take my family in her hands and break it apart. The drums seemed to be beating in my head.  The chanting -- the lights --  everything blurred together.  And then I heard a voice, speaking in a sudden silence.  My voice.  I was possessed.  I said that the woman at Fort Holland was evil and that the Houngan must maker her a Zombie.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And speaking of which, you have those market share charts Mr. Shackley was asking about?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Gotcha George, not a problem. Tomorrow. Hey, you want to start covering the old filmed entertainment sector yourself?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Ben you know that's your territory - and I wouldn't dream to trespass - you're the expert. Hey, how do you think Paramount's gonna do with that Blatty novel, what's it called? The Exorcist?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Overpriced bomb, cost over $6 million -- no stars, and no one's into the horror genre these days anyway. I'm advising the company recommend reducing positions there. It's disaster films that are gonna stay at the top.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Brilliant. Hey, you heading out a little early today?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Got a meeting uptown.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Right o'.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Up the organization!  Bastard.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Benjie!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Clair, George Clair! What the hell brings you to New Canaan?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, it's the funniest thing. I've been talking to some investors -- a little outside venture, you understand, between you and me -- about a scheme to manufacture a new Styrofoam packaging. Little peanut like pieces that can really keep an item free from trauma during shipping. Miraculous. Anyway, it turns out the genius behind the whole project is your neighbor, Jim Williams. How about that!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well, hey, isn't that a one-in-a million coincidence. A real dreamer, Jim Williams, eh?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Darned right. Look here, Benj, whaddya make of this sequel to The Godfather? You think it's gonna work?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Don't see how. I think the public's had its fill of this gangster stuff. No, trust me -- disaster pics. And air hockey.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, good.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, gonna make a break for the hors d'oeuvres guy.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah, see you bright and early Monday am.  Say, where's the wife?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: In Rhode Island with the folks. I'm a free agent tonight.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: OK, OK, the defense rests.  Want another?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: No thank you. We should be off.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Gotcha.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Don't be so modest, Ben. It's a job that requires a certain prescience with regards to entertainment trends. You were the first to predict that Billy Jack would be a hit --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: And as usual no one believed me...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You're staring at me.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I wasn't star--

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I've been thinking, Ben, about Wendy. I was going to ask if she'd come with me sometime to meet Dr. Woolens.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That shrink -- the one you always wanted me to see? I thought you dropped him.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I did, but -- somebody should probably see her, talk to her... You think she's ok?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Why shouldn't she be?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Then again, why should she be? I mean with us, with our...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: So maybe you'll come too?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh not again Elena! If we've got problems, why can't you just come out and talk about them.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: It's you Ben who needs to talk. I've had my say, and I'm waiting to hear back from you.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah but Elena, even you don't believe all that "I'm OK. You're OK" stuff you keep babbling about -- you say so yourself. I've been all ears for about ten years now on his subject, and --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: -- And you haven't moved out yet. It's because you're too lazy, Ben. Too scared or lazy to either deal with us or simply make a decision --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elena.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: The Halfords have invited us again this year.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You want to go?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well, it is a neighborhood tradition.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm, uh, going to bed.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: So early?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Rough day. Good night.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh yeah. Musk, or something. You like it?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Hmm. Good night.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You all right there?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Oh. Sure, I -- Did you remember to pick up the cranberry sauce?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Um, yes.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Because you like it on your turkey sandwiches.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I do. I'm -- are you...?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I... I think I am...

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You know Elena, I've been thinking--

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Ben, maybe no talking right now? If you start talking, you're going to--

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You crying?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm just sad Ben -- I mean it was... you were, but, you know. I just don't know...

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Whatever that means Elena -- And you complain about me not communicating... I thought it was --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: No, I didn't mean to sound negative. It was -- But Ben.  What is going to happen with us? Have you --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You have to bring this up now? What? Did I do something here? Is that it? Is it something I did?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I wasn't accusing you, Ben. It's just that we've got to be honest. Not just with ourselves, but with the children.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Hell, I know. I -- I guess if you want to accuse me, you've got --  Oh hell! I've got to pick up Paul. I almost forgot.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yikes -- I was hoping to wear this thing to the Halford's Friday.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: That shirt?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Leave it -- I'll wash it for you.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: The turkey in?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Stuffed and baking.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Dinner in ten minutes.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You go dry off now.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: In the basement over at Janey and Jim's. With that weirdo Mikey. Not even a TV on. And they're on the floor and he's got his trousers down though thank goodness she's still dressed. Well, I really let him have it!  ... and Wendy came home peacefully... Hey, should I dress for the Halford's now, or - give me your -

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Up to you. I'd like to go early and leave pretty soon after that.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I get you loud and clear... hey, you look nice.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: So what were you doing in the Williams' basement anyway?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh, just dropping off a coffee cup. Jim left it, last time he was over. It was on the dash of the car. You were, you know, reading, thought I'd just catch some air. Let's eat.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Oh right. The mustache coffee cup. The one that was sitting on the dash.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah, that one.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: That one.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What's for dessert?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: See for yourself.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No advice from the experts, huh?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Don't start.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You think I --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I have no idea.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What's on your mind? Don't --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: It wouldn't make a pleasant evening, if that's what you're after. I don't want to talk about it. Stupid mustache cup.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Don't be dim.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elena, what are you're talking about?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm not surprised.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Listen, Elena, if you're gonna pull that passive aggressive stuff on me again --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Your unfaithfulness -- that's what I'm trying to talk about. Your unfaithfulness. Your betrayal. Your dalliance. And you won't do me the dignity of being up front about it.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Am I unfaithful? Is that what you're trying to say?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: It's a starting place.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well, what kind of faithfulness are you after?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: If you're going to insult me --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What else could I be? What else could I be? We're not living in the real world here. You're living out some fantasy land from the past, or some advice or something from those psychoanalysts... there are some hard facts here.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Oh lord. You think I'm so dense. And now you want to be seen with your dense wife at the cocktail party. You want to wear that ridiculous shirt which doesn't go with those pants at all. You want to wear that, and you want me to shake hands with your friends and make conversation and dress up in an outfit that shows a lot of cleavage and you're not going to accord me the respect of talking honestly about this... You don't really know what this feels like.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Sure I do. Do I know what loneliness feels like? Sure I do. I know a lot about it, if that's what you mean.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Benjamin. That's supposed to explain it?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You've...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: In the car.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh, yeah. Yeah, we'll be right back, Dot.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: This just isn't the best moment for this.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I know, I know. I had no idea --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: That this was going to be a key party?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah, well, if we'd understood we could have invented some kind of excuse. A key party -- did you see how stuffed that bowl was already?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I think we're here and we don't have to stay -- we ought simply to put in an appearance and then we can head home.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Damn it, Ben --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm not staying at this party so we can go home with someone else's wife. That's not why we're here, right? We're simply being neighbors here, and I think we should do just that --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You're not going to --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm not.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You have some marker, that's what I think, if you want to know the truth. You have some marker and you're going to put it on the house keys so that Janey can find them and then when I get back to the house I'll find the two of you in there and Wendy'll be able to hear you and Paul will be back and he'll hear you and I'll catch you, that's what I think. She'll be swearing and banging against the wall and I'll catch --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elena.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elena, it's not what you think. It's not a big plot. Honestly. Honestly. I don't know if you want to go over this now, but it's just something that comes over me. I don't feel good about it. I know I've done what I didn't want to do. I don't know --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Well, I'm really pleased to hear a confession.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elena, you're just getting wound up to get wound up.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Thanks for the diagnosis, Ben. Thank you. So let's just go to this fiasco if that's what you want to do. Let's just go on in. I'd rather talk to anyone else but you.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Ready to go?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: We're not going anywhere.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elena.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Ben, I've got a ride home. Maybe you should sleep this one off on the couch here?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'll drive you --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Ben.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You'll get some sleep on the couch out there?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Sure. I'll try. And we'll talk in the morning?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: We'll talk in the morning.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Do you think? Maybe we should call someone --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: The phone's out.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah. Well, we can just --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Ben, I don't think he wants us here.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Oh you know, for a minute I thought it was --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Paul? Yeah. You think --

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hi dad.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Hey guy. Things ok up there? You all right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm fine dad.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well good. Just confirming. You'll be on the 3:50 Wednesday afternoon.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well dad, actually I thought I'd take the morning train on Thanksgiving -- got a lot of studying, papers, you know, lab experiments --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Lab experiments? Right smart guy -- Paul, you know your mother's gonna be disappointed not to see more of you -- In fact, let me make this more than a simple request guy, I think you should...

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: So how's school treating you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Classes?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Grades?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Anyone special? You know...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hnnn.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well it's good to see you -- we miss you around the house and all, but this St. Peter's, it's top of the line, eh?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You know Paul, I've been thinking, maybe this is as good a time as any to have a little talk, you know, about -- well --

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: About?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well, the whole gamut. Facts of life and all. Some fatherly advice, because, I tell you, there's things happening that you're probably old enough... well...  For example, on the self-abuse front -- now this is important - it's not advisable to do it in the shower -- it wastes water and electricity and because we all expect you to be doing it there in any case -- and, um, not onto the linen, and not on your sister's underwear or any clothing belonging to your mother --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Holy! Well. If you're worried about anything, just feel free to ask, and, uh, we can look it up.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uh, dad, you know I'm 16.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: All the more reason for this little heart to heart... great.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Um, Paul. On second thought, can you do me a favor and pretend I never said any of that.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sure dad.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: See you.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Stay out of trouble.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Ah let the guy have his fun. What's the name of this girl with the Park Avenue address?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Libbets. Libbets Casey.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Libbets? What kind of name is Libbets?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: It's like farming. I am basically chewing up large tracts of expensively landscaped scenery with overpriced sticks, and George Clair has obviously, in the mere two years since he joined the firm, he has obviously been taking secret lessons with a golf pro, and I assume the entirety of his disposable income has been devoted to humiliating me on the golf course. And the guy talks - incessantly -- throughout the entirety of the miserable 18 holes - on topics that are the supposed domain of my department --

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Ben--

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: You're boring me. I have a husband. I don't particularly feel the need for another.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You have a point there. That's a very good point. We're having an affair. Right. An explicitly sexual relationship. Your needs. My needs. You're absolutely right.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: You should probably get dressed. The boys will be home soon.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Gotcha.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: After the Thanksgiving I had, I need it. You having one?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: In a bit.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Maybe it's all for the better, you know? Yesterday, at dinner, well, she hasn't said anything... has she acted funny to you, I mean, have you noticed anything?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Have I noticed anything? I'm not married to her Benjamin, you are. I think you've probably a better vantage point from which to observe her.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah, but, I -- I've been working a lot lately, and -- No, that's not it. I guess we've just been on the verge of saying something, whatever it is, just saying something to each other. On the verge.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Birth control.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Right. Gotcha.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Oh jeez, Benjie. Well, here you are.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Damn right, but where the hell were you?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Don't bullshit me around, Janey. Jesus Christ, I waited around for more than half an hour, in nothing but my boxer shorts, and -- and what's all that about? What the hell happened?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: A prior engagement overcame me.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Listen, Benjamin Hood. I have obligations that precede your... from before you showed up. One or two, you know, good-natured encounters, that doesn't mean I'm... I'm not just some toy for you. When I remembered some chores I wanted to get done before the party, I just did them, that's all, because I wanted to do them before I saw Jimmy.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Jimmy? Jimmy? I don't know how to take this. And what do you mean, Jimmy? I thought you said you and your husband --

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: How you take it isn't all that interesting to me, Benjamin. I'm sorry --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I just can't believe you could be so --

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Dad stop it!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Get to sleep young lady -- and I mean it.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Fascist!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: If I were a fascist I would have sent you to one of those Southern military academies a long time ago. Now get to bed.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Good-night dad.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Good night kiddo.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm picking up Paul at the station - want to come?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What you been up to?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: ... while children in Africa and Asia are napalmed and --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Jesus all right enough!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What the hell are you kids doing down here?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: What do you think we're doing, dad?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What do I think? I think you're probably touching each other. I think you're touching that reckless jerk-off, for god's sake, and I think he's trying to get into your slacks. I think, at fourteen years of age, that you're getting ready to give up your girlhood --

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Talking to me, dad?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Who else would I be talking to? And take that thing off!

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Well, then forget all this stern dad stuff.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm not interested in your smart ass remarks now, lady. Let's go. Right now. You and I can discuss it on the walk home.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Look, kiddo, don't worry about it. I really don't care that much. I'm just not sure he's good enough, that's all.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I mean, he's not serious, he'll end up living off Janey and Jim, you watch. It's just that you develop a sense when you get older, if things are going to work out or if they won't, and sometimes it's not worth the mess...

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Your toes cold?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: He's probably been waiting all night at the station.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: C'mon.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: We don't have to always go to your club, dad.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And why are you still calling me dad? You're forty years old already, and --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: -- Well what am I supposed to call you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's besides the point.
